data.title: John Malkovich Made a Film None of Us Will Ever See
meta_keywords: 100 years - the movie you will never see
data.meta_description: Unless modern medicine finds a way to keep us alive until 2115 . . .
data.text:
As always, there are plenty of fascinating, odd movies in the Cannes Film Festival lineup this year. There’s Woody Allen’s Café Society, starring Kristen Stewart and Jesse Eisenberg, a movie called American Honey, starring Shia LaBeouf, a new Pedro Almodóvar flick called Julieta, and plenty more where that came from. But the race for Cannes’s weirdest project already has a clear winner, as a new film starring John Malkovich from director Robert Rodriguez will also make its debut at the festival . . . but in a safe. Where it will remain. Until 2115.

100 Years: The Movie You Will Never See is a Hollywood time capsule of sorts. The film imagines what Earth will be like a century from now, but will be locked away from human eyes until that time actually happens. The safe was specially designed to be impenetrable until it automatically opens in 2115. So, unless modern science makes some serious advancements (fingers crossed!), it’s safe to say that most of us reading this will never get a chance to watch it.

Clandestine nature aside, even films no one can watch need a press junket; the safe will travel the world—Los Angeles, Tokyo, Hong Kong, London, New York—before it lands in Cognac, France, where it will remain in the cellars of Louis XIII (the cognac, not the king who died in 1643). Hopefully they’re up to the task of protecting this nation’s now most precious secret from eager cinephiles, who by now have learned from plenty of movies how to break into places and steal stuff—preferably in teams of 11, 12, or 13, with the help of Mini Coopers, or with just Nicolas Cage on their side. But no matter—we’re sure they have top men working on it right now.

24 Delightful Star Wars: The Force Awakens Cameos You Might Have Missed
